awd_titl_txt: CNS Core: Small: A Software-Defined Approach to 5G Services for Robots
awd_abstract_narration:
Part I:

The global deployment of the 5G infrastructure is underway. This upcoming technology is envisioned to support billions of mobile users today and trillions of connected things tomorrow. Robotic applications are a new class of emerging applications for 5G, yet posing stringent requirements on low latency, high reliability, and high speed. In this project, we propose to innovate the 5G technology in its software stack (in the form of protocols) from the device side rather than inside the infrastructure. We use showcase robotic applications to drive our design effort. We challenge the conventional wisdom that wireless access is the sole roadblock for low latency and high reliability. Instead, we take the device perspective on 5G software innovation, which poses as an equally critical pathway from our initial results. We seek to achieve three goals. First, we refine the software stack of 5G for low latency within the standards from the device side. Second, we ensure high reliability through device-centric software techniques on the 5G system. Third, we provision 5G devices with new capabilities of both learning and reasoning for both common usage settings and failure-prone scenarios. If successful, it may help to advance robotic applications in our daily life and the society. The proposal further helps to train and prepare the next-generation workforce for 5G technology.

Part II:

The proposed research has three key areas of technical contributions. First, we use the robotic applications to drive our device-centric 5G innovations. It quantifies the requirements on low latency and high reliability, makes a case for software-defined reliability and latency tailored to applications, and offers benchmarks for assessing the design. Second, we take the device-centric approach to high reliability and low latency. Our solution leverages the state replica at the design and optimizes 5G latency on both control and data planes. To improve reliability, we exploit both concurrent network access (via connectivity to two base stations and multiple concurrent wireless channels to each) and detect-and-react for higher reliability. We devise novel proactive failure masking and reactive recovery components, by leveraging existing 5G mechanisms and recent checkpointing schemes. We further adjust various tuning knobs to the application's reliability requirement. Third, we provide new learning and reasoning functions at the device to open up the closed 5G network operations and enable the applications for further adaptations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The 5G network has been an important information infrastructure that supports a new generation of emerging applications, including automated robots, drone-based delivery, and smart vehcular information systems. However, the current 5G infrastructure is largely a closed system controlled by mobile carriers, thus preventing applications from leveraging new 5G capabilities. In this project, we take a fresh view from the user perspective. We provide a set of device-centric service primitives in three dimensions that can be readily exploited by emerging 5G applications.  First, we provide device-based low latency support over 5G networks. The applications can diagnose the 5G network latency bottleneck and reduce the access latency at the application level, without the commonly required root privilege. It uses a few dummy messages to learn the system parameters and reduce the latency components. Second, we enhance the system intelligence by unveiling the closed 5G system operations from the device side. We learn protocol operations and decision engines of 5G infrastructures through interacting with the 5G chipset and constructing appropriate analyzers for the network. Consequently, the device may make smart decisions despite the blackbox operations of 5G infrastructures. Third, we design a new SIM based solution to high reliability. We diagnose various types of 5G failures and use simple, multi-level resets/retries to recover from failures. Consequently, the 5G applications can continue to function in the presence of failures. In summary, we offer 5G applications the enhanced capabilities of low latency, high intelligence, and high reliability. Our solutions are software based and operated at the device side. It does not require 5G infrastructure upgrade or dedicated carrier support. Moreover, these appealing features are provided at marginal overhead on the 5G system. We have released the open-source version of our solution suite to the US research community. Our solutions are mostly plug and play software components. Our results will help the US industry to continue to lead the mobile Internet revolution and stay ahead by jumpstarting new applications.  Our software has also been used in undergraduate and graduate courses to help students learn the 5G system. We have further helped to train a new generation of graduate students and engineers who have joined the premier US companies to lead the 5G innovations.
